coredata.dc:title: New pyrene-based butterfly-shaped blue AIEgens: Synthesis, structure, aggregation-induced emission and their nondoped blue OLEDs
coredata.dc:creator: Yang, Xueli
Zhao, Zhen
Ran, Huijuan
Zhang, Jiali
Chen, Lijuan
Han, Ruijun
Duan, Xuewei
Sun, Huaming
Hu, Jian-Yong
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Developing the blue emitters with excellent electroluminescence (EL) performance is crucial for full-color displays and solid-state lighting. Based on the synthetic strategy for exploring highly efficient luminescent solids by constructing aggregation-induced emission (AIE) systems, two new pyrene-based butterfly-shaped blue AIEgens, Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, have been successfully designed and synthesized by integrating two tetraphenylethylene (TPE) or triphenylethylene (TriPE) groups into pyrene ring. The adoption of the pyrene unit with a large optical bandgap, the use of the TPE or TriPE group with AIE characteristic, the integration of the TPE or TriPE group into pyrene ring at 5,9-positions, and the highly twisted molecular conformations of present AIE systems endow the two compounds with bright blue emission in the solid state. These foregoing features ensure that the new pyrene-based compounds can serve as excellent blue-emitting materials in OLEDs. A non-doped OLED based on Py(5,9)BTPE exhibited a sky-blue emission (V on: 3.2 V) with a CIE coordinates of (0.19, 0.28), a maximum external quantum efficiency (EQEmax) of 3.35%, a current efficiency (CE) of 6.51 cd A−1 with a low efficiency roll-off that represents one of the highest value reported for sky-blue AIE-based OLEDs. An analogous device with Py(5,9)BTriPE as an emitting layer displayed a pure-blue emission (CIE: 0.16, 0.17) with a moderate EQEmax of 1.27% and a CE of 1.63 cd A−1 with a low efficiency roll-off. Furthermore, the EL emissions of the two devices display almost no change with the increasing of the current density, indicating their good color stability.
coredata.dcterms:subject: Aggregation-induced emission (AIE)
Pyrene
Phenylethylene
Blue AIEgens
Nondoped OLED

ce:caption.ce:simple-para: Structures of pyrene (up/middle) in Cartesian coordinates and 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenyl-5,9-dibromopyrene (1) (bottom) (left) and the representative pyrene-based AIEgens (right).
Molecular geometries, frontier molecular orbitals and the HOMOs/LUMOs of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE calculated by B3LYP/6-31G*.
TGA and DSC (inset, the second heating cycle) traces of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE recorded at a heating rate of 10 °C/min.

Single-crystal structures of Py(5,9)BTPE: (A) top view (up), (B) side view (bottom), (C) intermolecular interactions C–H⋅⋅⋅π (blue dashed lines) and (D) intermolecular stacking distance. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)
The UV–vis absorption spectra and PL spectra of Py(5,9)BTPE (a) and Py(5,9)BTriPE (b) in THF solution (1.0 × 10−5 M) and in thin flim.
PL spectra of Py(5,9)BTPE (a) and Py(5,9)BTriPE (b) in THF/H2O mixtures with different water fractions.

(a) Plots of fluorescence quantum yields of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, determinated in THF/H2O solutions versus water fractions; (b) quantum yields of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in THF solution and solid state (the inset shows their corresponding emission of powders) and (c) transient decay spectra of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in aggregated solid state.
Cyclic voltammograms of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in 0.1 M Bu4NPF6–CH2Cl2.

(a) EL spectra of Py(5,9)BTPE- and Py(5,9)BTriPE-based OLEDs along with their corresponding PL of thin films and (b) photos of device A (i) and device B (ii) and Commission Internationale de l’Eclairage (CIE) chromaticity coordinates (iii) of the two devices.

(a) Changes in current density and luminance with the applied voltages; (b) changes in current efficiency and power efficiency with the current density; (c) changes in external quantum efficiency with current density and (d) energy level diagrams and device configurations of Py(5,9)BTPE/Py(5,9)BTriPE-based OLEDs.
EL spectra stability of Py(5,9)BTPE- (a) and Py(5,9)BTriPE-based (b) nondoped OLEDs under different current densities.
Molecular structures and synthetic routes of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE.
Summary of photophysical and thermal properties of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Developing the blue emitters with excellent electroluminescence (EL) performance is crucial for full-color displays and solid-state lighting. Based on the synthetic strategy for exploring highly efficient luminescent solids by constructing aggregation-induced emission (AIE) systems, two new pyrene-based butterfly-shaped blue AIEgens, Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, have been successfully designed and synthesized by integrating two tetraphenylethylene (TPE) or triphenylethylene (TriPE) groups into pyrene ring. The adoption of the pyrene unit with a large optical bandgap, the use of the TPE or TriPE group with AIE characteristic, the integration of the TPE or TriPE group into pyrene ring at 5,9-positions, and the highly twisted molecular conformations of present AIE systems endow the two compounds with bright blue emission in the solid state. These foregoing features ensure that the new pyrene-based compounds can serve as excellent blue-emitting materials in OLEDs. A non-doped OLED based on Py(5,9)BTPE exhibited a sky-blue emission (V on: 3.2 V) with a CIE coordinates of (0.19, 0.28), a maximum external quantum efficiency (EQEmax) of 3.35%, a current efficiency (CE) of 6.51 cd A−1 with a low efficiency roll-off that represents one of the highest value reported for sky-blue AIE-based OLEDs. An analogous device with Py(5,9)BTriPE as an emitting layer displayed a pure-blue emission (CIE: 0.16, 0.17) with a moderate EQEmax of 1.27% and a CE of 1.63 cd A−1 with a low efficiency roll-off. Furthermore, the EL emissions of the two devices display almost no change with the increasing of the current density, indicating their good color stability.

ce:list-item.ce:para: Two pyrene-based blue AIEgens were designed and synthesized.
The AIE systems with highly twisted molecular conformations showed bright blue emission in the solid state.
Using Py(5,9)BTPE as the emitting layer, a high performance sky-blue nondoped OLED was fabricated.

ce:section.ce:para: Over the past few decades, organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) have attracted tremendous attentions for their promising applications in full-color displays and solid-state lighting [1–3]. With the dual innovation of luminescent materials and devices, high-efficiency luminescent green and red devices have been successfully developed for commercially applications [4–8]. However, it is worth noting that the performances of blue-emitting materials and devices still needs to be further improved [9]. As most organic luminescent materials, some of the blue-emitting materials that have been developed and reported face the phenomenon of Aggregation-Caused Quenching (ACQ) [10–12], which is unfavorable for the fabrication of high-efficiency OLEDs. In order to solve this problem, Tang et al., described the concept of Aggregation-Induced Emission (AIE) in 2001, where high-efficiency emission can be achieved by the limited motion of the “rotor” in the luminescent material structure in the aggregation state [13]. AIE luminogens (AIEgens) show negligible emission in solution but enhanced emission in the solid state. Furthermore, OLEDs based on the AIE materials could avoid the complex host-guest structure of the traditional OLEDs, and could effectively improve the stability of the device and also reduce the fabrication cost to a large extent [14–19].

Pyrene is a member of the polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) family (Fig. 1 ) and has attracted considerable attention in organic optoelectronic applications because of its good light-emitting properties [20]. However, owing to pyrene possesses a large planar π-conjugated aromatic system, it shows a strong π-π stacking and excimer formation, causing the quenched emission with a low photoluminescence quantum yield (PLQY) in the solid state. This is known as the notorious ACQ effect. In order to take full advantages of pyrene as light-emitting materials used in OLEDs, one of the efficient approaches is to develop pyrene-based AIEgens [21–33], in where bulky functional group with the AIE characteristic are introduced into the pyrene ring at appropriate positions. Examples of pyrene-based AIEgens substituted at 1- and/or 2-position, or 2,7-positions or 1-, 3-, 6- and 8-positions (Fig. 1) emit intensely in the solid state [21–23,26,28,32]. A nondoped OLED using TPPyE (Fig. 1) [23] mono-substutied at 1-position of pyrene as an emitter was fabricated, which gave a green-light at a turn-on voltage of 4.6 V with an external quantum efficiency (EQE) and a maximum current efficiency (CE) of 2.0% and 4.0 cd A−1, respectively. Using the di-substituted pyrene-based AIEgens (Py-2TP (Fig. 1) [28]) as an emitter, a nondoped blue OLED shows the EL performances with a turn-on voltage of 4.2 V, an EQEmax up to 3.46% and a CE of 2.94 cd A−1. For the tetra-substituted pyrene-based AIEgens, TTPEPy-based non-doped OLED (Fig. 1) [21] has the best performance with a turn-on voltage, a CE, and an EQE of 3.6 V, 12.3 cd A−1 and 4.95%, respectively. It should be mentioned here that all previously reported pyrene-based AIEgens were substituted by the corresponding AIE groups (i.e.: tetraphenylethylene (TPE), triphenylethylene (TriPE), etc.) at active sites (i.e.: 1-, 3-, 6-, and 8-positions) or planar nodes (i.e.: 2- and 7-positions) (Fig. 1), no AIEgens substituted at K-region (i.e.: 4-, 5-, 9-, and 10-positions) of pyrene ring are reported. Recently, we successfully brominated the 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenylpyrene [34] to 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenyl-5,9-dibromopyrene [35] (1) (Fig. 1), which provides a handle for introducing the AIE groups into pyrene ring at 5,9-positons of K-region to construct new AIEgens. In this contribution, we report the traditional synthetic techniques to synthesize two pyrene-based butterfly-shaped blue AIEgens (Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, Fig. 1). These two compounds are not only excellent blue emitters with AIE features, but also provide high-performance blue nondoped OLEDs. Among them, Py(5,9)BTPE shows remarkable AIE characteristic with a high PLQY in thin film and its nondoped OLED gave a sky-blue-light (CIE: 0.19, 0.28) at a low turn-on voltage of 3.2 V with a high EQE and a maximum CE of 3.35% and 6.51 cd A−1, respectively.

The molecular structures and synthetic routes of the proposed pyrene-based AIEgens (Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE) are illustrated in Scheme 1 . The two desired compounds were synthesized by Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reaction of the 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenyl-5,9-dibromopyrene [35] (1) with the corresponding pinacol ester of 1,1,2,2-tetraphenylethene (TPE) (2) or 1,1,2-triphenylethene (TriPE) (3) in high isolated yields [21]. The chemical structures of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE were fully characterized and confirmed by its FT-IR spectra, mass spectra, elemental analysis (see the Experimental section for details). No NMR spectra for these two compounds were obtained due to their limited solubility in organic solvents.

To study the electronic structures, density function theory (DFT) calculations were carried out on Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE using the B3LYP functional and the polarized 6-31G* basis set [36] (Fig. 2 ). The calculated dipole moments are 0.37 D for Py(5,9)BTPE and 0.26 D for Py(5,9)BTriPE, respectively, deriving from their weak polar symmetrical structures. The dipole moment difference between the two AIEgens could be due to their different symmetrical structures (Py(5,9)BTPE: an axisymmetrical structure and Py(5,9)BTriPE: a mirrior symmertrical structure). The calculated optimized geometries and frontier molecular orbitals are shown in Fig. 2 and calculated values are summarized in Table S1. In the optimized geometries of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, large dihedral angles of ca. 53–55° were observed between the pyrene ring and the phenyl rings at 1,3-positions that could be beneficial for suppressing the π-π stacking effectively in the solid state. On the other hand, the dihedral angles of ca. 54–56° and ca. 62–65° between the pyrene core and the phenyl rings of TPE/the vinyl planes at 5,9-positions were observed for Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, respectively. The connection of pyrene ring and the phenyl ring in Py(5,9)BTPE implys that a larger motion volume is required with respect to Py(5,9)BTriPE, which is possibly favorable to realize a more typical AIE effect in the aggregation state. In the calculated frontier molecular orbitals, for Py(5,9)BTPE, the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is mainly concentrated on the pyrene core and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is distributed on the pyrene core, while the four phenyl rings have a little contribution. For Py(5,9)BTriPE, its HOMO and LUMO are almost same that distributed on the center pyrene core, the two phenyl rings and the two vinyl planes. The calculated HOMOs and LUMOs of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE were −4.97/−4.88 eV and −1.62/−1.60 eV, respectively.

To fabricate OLEDs by vacuum thermal evaporation technique, high decomposition temperature (T d) is highly expected for the functional materials. The thermal properties of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE are carefully examined by the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) and differential scanning calorimetry (DSC). As shown in Fig. 3 and Table 1 , the two compounds have good thermal stabilities with a high T d of 451 °C for Py(5,9)BPTE and 428 °C for Py(5,9)BTriPE at 5% loss of initial weight, respectively. On the other hand, in DSC measurements, a high glass-transition temperature (T g) is recorded at 127 °C for Py(5,9)BTPE and 143 °C for Py(5,9)BTriPE, respectively, revealing their excellent morphologically stability. The results strongly demonstrated that these two newly developed pyrene-based AIEgens have promising potentials for the fabrications of stable OLEDs.

The structure of Py(5,9)BTPE was also confirmed by its single-crystal X-ray analysis [37] (Fig. 4 ). The crystal data of Py(5,9)BTPE are summarized in Table S2. Although several solvent systems were applied to Py(5,9)BTriPE, its single crystal can not still be prepared here. The single-crystal of Py(5,9)BTPE was successfully obtained by the sublimation technology. A noticeable feature in the molecular structure of Py(5,9)BTPE is its highly twisted molecular conformation. The dihedral angles of Py(5,9)BTPE between the pyrene ring and the four phenyl rings are ca. 41-62° (Fig. 4A/4B), which are beneficial for inhibiting the π−π stacking effectively, thus, the emission-quenching could be effectively suppressed. The results are well agreed with its DFT calculations. In addition, abundant intermolecular interactions such as C–H⋅⋅⋅π interactions in the single-crystal of Py(5,9)BTPE were observed (Fig. 4C), which could possibly rigidify its molecular conformation and restrain the molecular motion, resulted in the possibility of AIE effect with bright emission in the solid state. The packing structures of Py(5,9)BTPE can be described as an irregular packing form neither J-aggregations [38–41] or H-aggregations [42] (Fig. S2). Furthermore, large packing distances (ca. 10.029 Å and 12.520 Å) between neighboring molecules in the single-crystals of Py(5,9)BTPE were observed, implying the π-π stacking or excimer formation were completely inhibited (Fig. 4D).

The absorption spectra of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in THF solutions (10−5 M) and thin films are shown in Fig. 5 . The two compounds displayed broad π-π* absorption bands at 350–400 nm, originating from the extended conjugation lengths of the pyrene chromophores with the TPE or TriPE units at the 5,9-positions. In solution case, both luminogens have similar absorption spectral profiles, with a absorption maxima located at 371 and 382 nm for Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, respectively. A red-shift of ~11 nm for Py(5,9)BTriE was observed with respect to Py(5,9)BTPE, which is possibly attributed to its larger π-electron delocalization. In thin film case (vacuum evaporation, 50 nm), the absorption spectrum of Py(5,9)BTPE is broader (~5 nm red-shift) than its solution without a vibronic feature characteristic, which possibly due to both the change of its molecular comformation and the intermolecular interactions such as C–H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. In contrast, the absorption spectrum of Py(5,9)BTriPE is almost same (ca. ~1 nm red-shift) with its solution, implying both no change of its molecular comformation and its weak intermalecualr interactions. The PL spectra (excitation wavelength: 370 nm) of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in THF solutions (10−5 M) and thin films (vacuum evaporation, 50 nm) are also shown in Fig. 5. In solution case, Py(5,9)BTPE displays a red-shift emission (419 nm) than Py(5,9)BTriPE (411 nm), originating from its larger π-conjugation molecular structure. In thin film case, for Py(5,9)BTPE, a larger red-shift of ~72 nm was observed than its solution, which can also be ascribed to both the change of its molecular comformation and the strong intermolecular interactions that agreed with its single-crystal X-ray analysis. For Py(5,9)BTriPE, a red-shift of ~42 nm was observed than its solution, which mainly due to the intermolecular interactions. The solvatochromism for Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE were measured in different solvents with varying polarity. Both compounds showed a slightly solvatochromic behavior either in absorption or in emission (Fig. S4 and Fig. S5). This phenomenon was further presented by the relationship between the Stokes-shifts in various solvents and the Lippert equation [43,44], in which a linear correlation between the two factors were obtained (Fig. S6). All photophysical data are summarized in Table 1 and Table S3.

In order to illustrate the PL behaviors of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in the aggregated state, their PL spectra (excitation wavelength: 370 nm) in THF/water mixture containing different fractions of water (f w) were then examined [45]. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the PL intensity of Py(5,9)BTPE intensifies swiftly at f w ≥ 40%, then reaches to the maximum at water fraction of 90% and shows a remarkable AIE characteristic [13]. This phenomenon can be explained that Py(5,9)BTPE is insoluble in the water, the intramolecular motion, which is active in solution, is restricted in the aggregated state and the nonradiative decay of the excited state is suppressed [46,47]. Consequently, the excited state energy can be released as photons efficiently, making PL intensity increase rapidly. On the other hand, when the water fractions ranged from 40% to 90%, its emission peak red-shifts to ~13 nm. This abnormal phenomenon might originates from the transition from the crystalline state to the amorphous one, as well-proven and explained in previous reported cases [48–50]. Interestingly, compared to Py(5,9)BTPE, Py(5,9)BTriPE shows different PL behaviors in THF/water mixture. When the f w ranged from 10% to 50% in the mixture, the PL intensity is increased gradually, indicating the formation of aggregation with a weak AIE characteristic, further ranged the f w from 50% to 90%, its PL intensity is rapidly decreased to some extent, rendering a mild ACQ effect [46]. The results indicate that the introduction of the TPE or TriPE group with AIE characteristic into pyrene ring at 5,9-positions could bring an apparently different properties of AIE and ACQ.

The PLQYs of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE were fully measured in solutions, powders and thin films, respectively (Table 1). As shown in Fig. 7a/7 b, for Py(5,9)BTPE, much energy could consumed through intramolecular rotations in dilute THF solution (10−5 M), resulting in a negilible PLQY value of 0.4% [51–53]. A high PLQY value up to 53.5% was obtained in the aggregation state with a f W = 90%, thus, from being nearly non-emissive in the solution state, i.e., it was AIE-active. For Py(5,9)BTriPE, a PLQY value of 30.8% was observed in dilute THF solution (10−5 M), a higher PLQY value up to 33.7% was obtained in the aggregation state with a f W = 50%, and a lower PLQY value of 19.8% was obtained in the aggregation state with a f W = 90%, respectively, thus, implying it was AIE-active in the f w of 10–50% and ACQ effect in the f w of 50–90%, respectively. A lower PLQY value of 14.4% was obtained in the powder for Py(5,9)BTriPE, in contrast, a larger PLQY value of up to 55.3% was achieved for Py(5,9)BTPE [54] (Fig. 7b). On the other hand, in order to illustrate the different PL behaviour of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE in the aggregated state, transient PL spectra (excitation wavelength: 370 nm) were measured and the corresponding decay curves (PL: 450 nm for Py(5,9)BTPE and 410 nm for Py(5,9)BTriPE) are displayed in Fig. 7c. The fluorescence lifetimes (τ) of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE are 1.69 and 2.36 ns, respectively (Table 1). On the basis of these data, the corresponding radiative decay rates (K r) and the nonradiative decay rates (K nr) were calculated according to the formulas: K r = QY/τ and K nr = 1/τ-K r [55]. A larger K r value of 3.3 × 108 s−1 and a more smaller K nr value of 2.6 × 108 s−1 were attained for Py(5,9)BTPE compared with Py(5,9)BTriPE (K r = 6.7 × 107 s−1 and K nr = 3.6 × 108 s−1), respectively, determinating the higher emission efficiency for the former in aggregation state [55].

To evaluate the practical HOMO and LUMO energy levels, the electrochemical behavior of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE are measured by cyclic voltammetry (CV). The results reveal that Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE have similar reversible oxidation/reduction peaks (Fig. 8 ), demonstrating their good electrochemical stability. The oxidation peaks are at 1.15 and 1.14 V, and onset oxidation potentials (E onset) are at 1.05 and 1.0 V for Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE, respectively. The HOMOs of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE are calculated to be −5.48 and −5.44 eV, respectively, according to the equation of HOMO = −(E onset + 4.8 − E Fc/Fc+) eV. The LUMOs are −2.48 and −2.46 eV for Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE from the equation of LUMO = (HOMO + E g) eV, respectively, where E g is the optical bandgap obtained from the absorption onset (Table 1). The HOMOs of Py(5,9)BTPE (−5.48 eV) and Py(5,9)BTriPE (−5.44 eV) are close to that of N,N′-bis(naphthalen-1-yl)-N,N′-bis(phenyl)benzidine (NPB) [2] (−5.70 eV) and the LUMOs of Py(5,9)BTPE (−2.48 eV) and Py(5,9)BTriPE (−2.46 eV) are comparable to 1,3,5-tris(1-phenyl-1H-benzimidazol-2-yl)benzene (TPBi) (−2.8 eV), which are favorable for a good hole/electron-injection in the fabrication of OLEDs [56,57].

In summary, two new pyrene-based butterfly-shaped blue AIEgens (Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE) were designed and synthesized. The two AIEgens exhibited high thermal stability and possessed the glass-formation property with high T g. Their AIE behaviors have been carefully studied. They have bright blue emission in the solid state benefited from the molecular design strategy. These attractive features endowed these compounds with excellent EL performance. A sky-blue nondoped OLED with high performance (EQEmax: 3.35%, CEmax: 6.51 cd A−1 and PEmax: 6.24 lm W−1) has been realized by using Py(5,9)BTPE as the emitting layer, and a pure-blue nondoped OLED with modorate performance (EQEmax: 1.27%) has been constructed by using Py(5,9)BTriPE. It is notable that the Py(5,9)BTPE-based nondoped device is one of the most efficient sky-blue devices with AIE compounds as the emitting material. The present contribution confirms that AIE-type compounds are promising materials for highly-efficient blue OLEDs with excellent color purity, and the molecular design strategy presented in this study encourages us to further develop pyrene-based blue AIEgens.

The experiment was carried out according to the reported methods [21]. Stock THF solutions of Py(5,9)BTPE and Py(5,9)BTriPE were prepared with a concentration of 10−4 M. Aliquots of the stock solutions were transferred to 10 mL volumetric flasks. After appropriate amounts of THF were added, water was added dropwise under vigorous stirring to prepare 10−5 M solutions with different water contents. The PL spectra of the resultant solutions were recorded immediately.

Synthesis of 7-tert-Butyl-1,3-diphenyl-5,9-dibromopyrene (1) [35]. A solution of Br2 (0.03 mL, 0.5 mmol) and CH2Cl2 (2 mL) was added dropwise to a mixture of 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenylpyrene [34] (100 mg, 0.5 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (4 mL) at −78 °C for 6 min and stirred for 20 min under N2 atmosphere. The resulting mixture was allowed to stir overnight. The reaction mixture was poured into ice water and neutralized with a 10% aqueous solution of Na2S2O3. The mixture solution was extracted with dichloromethane. The organic layer was washed with water and brine and then the solution was dried (MgSO4) and condensed under reduced pressure. The residue was purified by column chromatography eluting with CH2Cl2/n-hexane (1 : 7). Recrystallization from CH2Cl2/n-hexane (2:1) gave 1 (166 mg, 71%) as a light-yellow powder. 1H NMR (300 MHz, CDCl3): δ = 8.73 (s, 2H), 8.54 (s, 2H), 7.96 (s, 1H), 7.46–7.66 (m, 10H), 1.64 (s, 9H) ppm. 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3) δ = 150.72, 140.21, 137.57, 130.62, 130.09, 129.76, 128.90, 128.73, 127.82, 124.94, 123.86, 123.73, 123.26, 35.90, 32.01. Anal. Calcd for C32H24Br2: C, 67.63; H, 4.26; found: C, 67.66; H, 4.24.

Synthesis of 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenyl-5,9-bis(4-(1,2,2-triphenylvinyl) phenyl)pyrene (Py(5,9)BTPE) [21]: A solution of 2 (1.04 g, 1.83 mmol), 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-2-(4-(1,2,2-triphenylvinyl)phenyl)-1,3,2-dioxaborolane (2.50 g, 5.50 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (0.32 g, 0.28 mmol), and potassium carbonate (3.80 g, 27.50 mmol) in degassed toluene/ethanol/water mixture (8:2:2: v/v/v 120 mL) was heated to reflux for 24 h under nitrogen. The precipitate was washed with water, acetone and collected by filtration. After drying under vacuum, the crude products were purified by sublimation under vacuum gave Py(5,9)BTPE (1.14 g, 58%) as a yellow solid. Mp. 290 °C. ν max (KBr)/cm−1: ν = 3025 (=C–H), 1590 (CC). 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 50 °C): δ = 8.17 (s, 2H), 8.08 (s, 2H), 7.92 (s, 1H), 7.66 (d, J = 8 Hz, 4H), 7.51 (t, J = 16 Hz, 6H), 7.41 (t, J = 16 Hz, 2H), 7.34 (d, J = 8 Hz, 4H), 7.19–7.09 (m, 32H), 1.47 (s, 9H). MS (MALDI-TOF): m/z calcd. for C84H62 1070.49; Found 1070.58 [M+H]+. Anal. Calcd for C84H62: C, 94.17; H, 5.83%. Found: C, 94.15; H, 5.84%.

Synthesis of 7-tert-butyl-1,3-diphenyl-5,9-bis(1,2,2-triphenylvinyl) pyrene (Py(5,9)BTriPE) [21]: A solution of 2 (1.10 g, 1.94 mmol), 4,4,5,5-tetramethyl-2-(1,2,2-triphenylvinyl)-1,3,2-dioxaborolane (3.72 g, 9.72 mmol), Pd(PPh3)4 (450 mg, 0.39 mmol), and potassium carbonate (5.38 g, 38.88 mmol) in degassed toluene/ethanol/water mixture (8:2:2: v/v/v 120 mL) was heated to reflux for 24 h under nitrogen. The precipitates was washed with water, acetone and filtrated. After drying under vacuum, the crude products were purified by sublimation under vacuum gave Py(5,9)TriPE (0.93 g, 52%) as a pale yellow solid. Mp. 272 °C. ν max (KBr)/cm−1: ν = 3052 (=C–H), 1591 (CC). No NMR spectra was measured because of its limited solubility in organic solvents. MS (MALDI-TOF): m/z calcd. for C72H54 918.42; Found 918.47 [M+H]+. Anal. Calcd for C72H54: C, 94.08; H, 5.92%. Found: C, 94.04; H, 5.94%.
DFT calculations, Single-crystal X-ray analysis, FT-IR spectrum, PL spectra, 1H/13C NMR spectra and MS spectra were described in Supplementary Date.
The authors declare no competing financial interest.
